name: Rena
comment info:
I notice that the quartiles of second-generation immigrants are roughly equal, hovering around 20%. In comparison, there is a significant disparity between the percentiles of children of US-born fathers in the lowest and highest classes. There is more than three times the number of children of US-born fathers classified as poor than rich. This is consistent throughout the social classes of people with native-born fathers; the number of people in a certain class decreases as their money increases. 
I wonder how the experiences of immigrant fathers affected their children’s drive to rise in social class. Were the children themselves born in the US? Is this phenomenon restricted to the variables imposed on this population? For example, what if it included the children of immigrant mothers? Is there something intrinsic to foreign paternity that induces social fluidity? What is the significance of measuring the income level of people in their mid-thirties? Does their age bracket cause bias because people of their age often have not yet finalized their social standing? What percentage of each population attended college?
This infographic shows politicians and lawmakers the importance of allowing people from other countries to establish citizenship in America and improve both the US economy and their own situations a single generation later.
Second-Generation Immigrants vs. the American Dream

name: Darya Dumon
comment info:
What do you notice? 
Overall, the household income of parents influences the household income of their children but there is a difference based on whether they are children of immigrants or US born children. For children of immigrants, 43% of children born into families in the lowest 20% income bracket remain poor or lower middle class, whereas, 57% of US born children in the lowest 20% bracket remain poor or lower middle class. Conversely, 35% of these children born to immigrants, move up to the upper middle class or become rich, in comparison to only 25% of the US born children. 15% of children of immigrants in the lowest income bracket are rich in their mid-thirties, but only 9% of US born children become rich.

name: FB
comment info:
The thing that I immediately notice about this graph is that of people who became rich, a higher percentage are the children of immigrants. This is out of people who were born into the lowest 20% of all household incomes in America between 1978 and 1983, so I'm curious if there is a particular reason for choosing this age bracket. I also notice that children of U.S born men have greater percentages in the poor and lower-middle class brackets, but once the middle class category is reached, children of immigrants have the higher percentages. I wonder what this graph would look like if it used people who are older than those in this graph, or what it would look like in the future. I think seeing whether this data remains consistent would help to back the argument in the opinion piece "Why So Many Children of Immigrants Rise to the Top" by Peter Coy, where the interactive version of the graph is included. 

I think this graph is relevant to my community because I there are people everywhere from all sorts of different backgrounds, and often times you don't know everything that someone went through or is going through in their life.

I would title this graph "Is the American Dream Obtainable?"

name: Anushka Joshi
comment info:
What do you notice: I notice that children of immigrants tend to fall under higher classes even rich classes than U.S.-born children. This surprises me because I would first think U.S.-born children would be more successful because they might understand "the lay of the land" better than immigrant-born children but my assumptions are proven wrong by the data of this graph. 

Wonder: I wonder if U.S.-born children tend to be less successful because they might have more to live up to in the sense that their predecessors have started businesses where children could just work rather than attempt to start their own career path. This could set back U.S.- born children whereas immigrant-born children are stereotyped as tireless workers because their parents have come to this country purely for the opportunities and may have no option but to work hard to live and succeed. 

Community affect: As a child of immigrants, I genuinely do believe my parents have different standards and goals for me than some of my friends whose parents are U.S.-born citizens although I think it important to remember that children of immigrants are not their parents. There are different paths we take in our life because we live in almost 2 cultures, our parent's and American culture. The perspective of an immigrant parent is different than a child of an immigrant also known as a third culture child.

Title: Third culture Kids...

name: Emilia AOSE
comment info:
The first thing that I notice about the graph is that children brought into households in the lowest 20% of all family incomes is that, whether born to immigrants or lifelong US residents, are least likely to become part of the rich upper class. Children of immigrants generally have more success bettering their financial status. They have higher percentages of people ranging from the middle, upper-middle, and upper class. Children of US-born parents, consequently, are more concentrated in the poor and lower-middle classes. As a result of stereotypes, I believe it would surprise most people to learn that children of immigrants climb the social ladder more rapidly. 
I wonder how connected motivation is to the higher success rates in social climbing in children of immigrants. I also wonder what the main contributed to such high poverty rates is--lack of housing and jobs, addiction issues, family issues, etc. 
This relates to my community because a large portion of my town consists of immigrants and children of immigrants. In addition, where I live is near some of the most concentrated immigrant populations, like Newark, where a lot of Ellis Island immigrants came to the US to live.

name: Tim
comment info: It's been awhile since I took stat classes, but almost every time I see a graph or chart in the media, one of my first questions is "what are the error bars around these estimates?" A 1% difference in the middle class numbers may be significant, an eight percent difference in the poor numbers may not. You can't tell, so further "analysis" of the numbers is just speculation. (BTW, another of my first questions is "who funded the study?" That gives me a clue about how hard I should look at the numbers.)

name: Cesar
comment info:
What do you notice?
I first noticed that overall, the children of immigrants have a higher level of income than U.S born children. While U.S born children are higher in percentage for poor and lower middle household income (29%:21% and 28%:22% respectively), immigrant children have a higher percentage for middle and upper middle class, as well as the rich category (22%:21%, 20%:14%, and 15%:9% respectively). The percentages for the immigrants also look a lot more evenly distributed while the U.S born children’s percentages are more skewed. I also noticed that immigrant children added up to 100% but due to rounding, the U.S born children added up to 101%.

What do you wonder?
I wonder who wrote the book in which this data was shown and how the person(s) who collected the data collected it. Was it taken through the use of a survey or was it through some other method? I also wonder why more children of immigrants are more likely to change the level of income they have when compared to U.S born children. Is it because of how they were raised, their mindset, or is it something else?

How does this relate to you and your community?
This graph relates to my community and I because my parents themselves were immigrants and moved here to the U.S for better opportunities. It could also serve to motivate people around me to change their financial situations for the better.

Headline:
The American Dream May Not Be So American

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
There are some comments here that compare percentages from the infographic.  Note the distinction between --

PERCENTAGE POINT DIFFERENCE is the difference between two percentages and is expressed as a number. It can be either a positive, negative, or zero.

PERCENTAGE DIFFERENCE is the difference between two percentages divided by the baseline percentage and is expressed as a percentage. Percentage difference can be either negative, positive, or zero.

The PERCENTAGE POINT DIFFERENCE between "rich" children of U.S. born and children of immigrants is...

The PERCENTAGE DIFFERENCE between "rich" children of U.S. born and children of immigrants is...

The answers to these two questions are different.  Which question, in your opinion, best describes the difference between these two groups?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Zamaya --

I don’t know what you mean by “the participants' range was very specific.”  Please explain.  

Good wonder about what the “ranges of money” is.  These are quintiles – dividing national income into five groups, each with the same number of households.  

For 2020, the lowest quintile is all household incomes less than or equal to $27,026, second quintile is $27,027 - $52,179, middle quintile is $52, 180 - $85,076, fourth quintile is $85,077 - $141,110 and the top quintile is greater than $141,110.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Joseph Martellucci --

Thank you for your noticings.  

Be careful about using the word correlation.  In statistics, correlation involves analysis of two or more quantitative variables, like weight and height.  

If you are analyzing with qualitative (or categorical) variables, we say association. Here, we could discuss the association between where children’s parents are born and their income at 30 years old.  

Take another look at the graph with all of its titles and labels.  What do you now notice and wonder?

name: Nicholas
comment info: The first thing that I noticed when looking at the graph is that poor second generation immigrants have a significantly higher likelihood of becoming rich compared to poor U.S. born citizens. Although a larger percentage of U.S. born children are born into poverty than the children of immigrants are born into poverty, they have similarly proportionate chances of advancing into the lower and middle classes. However, I noticed that children of immigrants have nearly double the chance of becoming rich compared to U.S. born children. In the case of many second generation immigrants, it is possible that their parents face the large burden of leaving their home country and adapting to a new environment, thus making it difficult to immediately thrive economically. The first generation immigrants’ undertaking of most of the initial struggles of starting new life likely set up their children for greater opportunities and success. To add onto that, I wonder if it would be possible to measure or gather some form of data regarding motivation and the “seizing” of opportunity. I wonder what the distribution of these statistics would look like across different ethnic groups or native countries. It would also be interesting to see which states in the U.S., appeared to lead to greater second generation success. If I had to guess I would assume that many second generation immigrants find success in New York, California, and Florida.
